narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The ablilty to watch the recorded lecture in case I felt that I had missed any material was very helpful.
Recorded lecture + live virtual lecture with discussion format
also recorded
Live virtual lecture + recorded lecture

We had live lecture/Q&A for every scheduled class period. It was largely interactive, which I appreciated. Often, for homework, we did readings, watched Coursera videos, and took Canvas quizzes. It was a good mix of different modes of learning.
We had to watch prerecorded lectures and then also attend live virtual lecture
A combination of pre-recorded lectures and live virtual discussions!
Coursera, readings, recorded lectures
Online modules and quizzes
Included, pre-recorded lectures, writing seminar sessions, and live lectures.
Also recorded lectures

Live lectures were recorded, but the instructors preferred we attend the lecture live. We also followed a flipped classroom model where we watched asynchronous lectures and reviewed the material/questions in the live lecture.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a great deal about the financial crisis, and many associated financial concepts.

I gained many insights on the Global Financial Crisis that I had not known beforehand.  Specifically, I learned about what makes a crisis, the lead-up to the crisis of 2008, and reactions not only in the United States, but in Europe as well.
I learned about the causes and consequences of the Global Financial Crisis, from securitization to the global savings glut to the Eurozone crisis.
I learned about the Global Financial Crisis and its causes/effects. You learn a lot about how the financial system operates and discuss what exactly led to the crisis.

I learned about the causes, events, policy responses, and aftermath of the global financial crisis. I also learned about how lessons from the crisis might be applied to the current COVID-19 situation. I practiced memo- and paper-writing.

I learned about the causes and consequences of the Global Financial Crisis. This was a really instructive course to understand what happened in 2008, from the housing bubble to securitization to the policy decisions enacted in 2008.
I learned so much about the causes of the global financial crisis. Goes into a great amount of detail above and beyond the Big Short concepts. The readings were very interesting and helpful.
Improve writing skills, get better at evaluating research, and gained a better understanding of the US financial system
I gained a comprehensive understanding of the history of financial crises. I have a much better grasp of how capital markets function and how policy relates to financial regulation.
How to think about the financial crisis and evaluate response to future crises.
You delve deep into what caused the financial crisis and its effect on the rest of the world.
Understanding the gfc

I developed an understanding of basic financial knowledge that is applied to learning about the global financial crisis. I also expanded my writing skills since I took the writing portion of the class. I thought this course was helpful towards developing these skills.
In depth ev

We learned about different aspects of the 2008 Global Financial Crisis: its buildup and causes in the United States, the events of the crisis, how it spread to Europe, and different regulatory responses. We reviewed different types of sources about the crisis including empirical analyses, firsthand accounts of leaders during the crisis like Secretary Timothy Geithner, and books about the crisis. In learning about the crisis we learned about the financial system its relationship to the real economy as well as the current measures in place due to COVID-19 that may help prevent another financial crisis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
the course is generally quite interesting, and functions well in its current format. 

one tiny complaint: with respect to the recorded modules, I'd appreciate if more information was conveyed visually rather than by audio alone.

While the live lectures were interesting, they would often go off on tangents that didn't feel very applicable to the assignments.  Watching a pre-recorded lecture along with attending a live lecture is quite a time commitment.  Other than that, I enjoyed the material of the class very much.

Strengths: recorded lectures were succinct and to the point, allowing for a broader understanding of the GFC. Paper 2 and the final paper allowed a chance to dig deeper into course content. Prof. Metrick is awesome & really engaging.

Weaknesses: live, in-person lectures were not really necessary to attend because very little content was covered; it was largely geared toward answering complex theoretical questions from graduate students. The grading of assignments is quite nebulous and subjective. The writing credit should not be optional considering the four memos and three papers that must be written. The first paper assignment which required reading a book was not particularly helpful in understanding of the crisis.
got very repetitive after the halfway mark of the course

Strength: Professor Metrick is a fantastic teacher and is a really interesting and dynamic lecturer. I also think the assignments (though slightly difficult) are also really good at making sure that I understood the material.

Weaknesses: Writing the memos are a bit stressful in a short time frame, but was mostly manageable. Being graded out of 8 leaves fairly minimal room for error, though.

No weaknesses! I loved everything about the course. Professor Metrick and his TAs were spectacular. I appreciated how the class lectures weren't just a repeat of what we learned in our Coursera lectures, which we sometimes watched for homework (so no, you aren't just paying Yale tuition to take a Coursera course). Rather, Metrick would often make the class session interactive, answering our questions as they came up. He did a great job tying in current events, too. I liked the assignments. The quizzes and community contributions were pretty straight-forward and kept me engaged. The memos and papers were definitely more difficult, but I learned a ton during the writing process.

Strengths: Class attendance not required
Weaknesses: Obnoxious students in the class; Geithner only shows up like three times

Strengths: Really interesting content for anyone who wants to learn about the 2008 crisis. Given the historical importance of 2008, I think it's great for anyone to learn more about what caused the crisis and how we can deal with crises when they arise. I liked the prerecorded lectures on Coursera and the guest lectures from Timothy Geithner were great.

Weaknesses: This course can be a lot of work and grading seems arbitrary. You write a minimum of 4 memos, but a maximum of 9, and then keep your top grades  even though the memos are short, they take a lot of time to write. Also, expectations for the memos are confusing, since writing workshops encourage brevity, but then grading favors pieces that are more verbose. Furthermore, there are two longer response papers and then a final paper, all of which take a ton of time to finish. Plus, you have to watch prerecorded lectures and take a quiz before almost every lecture, and then still attend in person live lecture
Well organized course.
There could have been more TA feedback to help us improve our writing. The class was well structured with online lectures though, and Professor Metrick was extremely engaging.
Metrick is an amazing lecturer. I wish he would be more understanding of student circumstances when imposing harsh deadlines (especially given the pandemic).

Strengths: it's great to hear Sec. Geithner's first hand experience, and Prof. Metrick's more academic analysis.

Weaknesses: I wasn't a big fan of the "watch the lectures beforehand" way of teaching. It's cool that class time is devoted to asking questions, but I'd much rather preferred live lectures where the professor discussed the material and not just answered questions.
I thought it was an outstanding course

The class could be tremendously improved if the pre-recorded lectures were actually taught during class time. This would allow for greater class engagement and make live lectures more important to attend. Otherwise, the live lectures are just question and answer sessions between the prof and grad students.

The main strength of this course is that there are multiple ways to learn the material. There are the asynchronous lectures you are required to watch before class, the opportunity to post questions to the discussion board which may be answered in class, readings, and several writing exercises. While there is a lot of work for this course, a lot of it covers the same material and/or reviews older concepts, allowing you to take away - at the very least - a general understanding of how financial crises originate and spread to the financial system and real economy. The other strength of this course is access to some of the leading thinkers/researchers on financial stability. I also liked the fact that there are multiple opportunities to improve your grade (e.g. write 4/9 memos, several opportunities to get participation points, drop 2 lowest quizzes, etc.). Theoretically, this incentivizes students to keep trying to improve their grades and gain even more proficiency in the material. My problems with the course were mostly with how the assignments were spread out during the term, but I think that came down to poor time management on my part.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that if the same structure is to stand, that is a pre-recorded lecture and an live lecture, then the live lecture should be made optional.  4 total lectures within a week is too much of a time commitment in my opinion.
Discussion questions allowed for virtual engagement, and I think it was pretty interesting to hear Metrick answer these questions in real time.

All of them succeeded! At the beginning, Metrick said that the course had been taught in a somewhat hybrid fashion even before COVID-19, so transitioning to fully virtual wouldn't be tough at all. He was right. Even pretty late in the semester, there was a fair amount of class participation; people were still asking great questions and, to some extent, giving Metrick pushback whenever they thought he said something incorrect.

I think it would have been better to have either live virtual lecture or prerecorded lecture, but not both. Since live lecture was just about answering questions, it felt less engaging than the prerecorded lectures, which contained the bulk of the course content
Recorded lecture models and readings were great. The synchronous lectures where professor metrick answers questions werent that helpful or a great use of my time tbh.
I think recorded lectures need to become part of in person classes when that happens. It's extremely helpful
The SOM classroom was helpful, although I never had a chance to attend the class in person.
Metrick wanted to bring guests in, didn't really happen. Loved hearing from Timothy Geithner.
I thought it worked perfectly as a virtual course
The class was well designed for a pandemic. Perhaps sections would have increased engagement and the overall takeaways from the course.
The course went really well and the teacher made it interesting

This course offered multiple ways to engage with the material and instructors during the pandemic. The main one was the opportunity to earn participation points by posting questions on the discussion board, which could be answered in class. From what I understood, this class was conducted in a similar way even before the pandemic (except for in-person lectures), and I think the existing format translated well to an online one.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: this is a fairly interesting course, especially if you like financial history or political economy. Be prepared for a fair amount of writing, though
I would recommend this course to someone interested in learning more about the inter-workings of a financial crisis, but who is aware of the time commitment.

I would not recommend this course to another undergraduate student (at least over Zoom) because there was very little value-added  most of the content was simply covered in Coursera modules and videos, and the remaining assignments, of which there were many, felt a lot like busy work. As a result, I do not think this course is worth one of your Yale credits. While Prof. Metrick is a great professor, the course structure is not the most interactive and the grading can be a bit strict as well.

Yes! I would recommend this course if you're interested in how our financial system works and of course, the Global Financial Crisis. If you come in knowing nothing about the financial system like I did, there is a bit of a small learning curve, but it ends up being a really interesting and rewarding course, since I found that I could discuss the subject pretty coherently at the end.

Absolutely! I learned a ton about the global financial crisis, which is more relevant even now than you might think. Professor Metrick is amazing, and you should definitely try to take a class with him before you graduate. It was nice having a bunch of SOM students in the class, since they have such interesting backgrounds and insights. Also, the TAs are great (and highly qualified).

Certainly not for Yale College students - the grading curve is only based on the other undergrads in the course, who score way higher on everything than the rest of the class and make it extremely difficult to achieve a good grade
I'd recommend this course to anyone interested in learning more about 2008, but this is NOT a good fifth class. The workload can be heavy
Yes definitely would recommend to any finance or non-finance students as learning about the causes of the GFC is so important.
Yes. Good professor and interesting material
Yes, definitely. It was very interesting course material.
Yes!
Yes, great class if you're interested in the financial system and how it can go wrong.
Professor metrick is incredible and the course is very insightful into the gfc
I would recommend this course but only if class material was taught during class rather than in the pre-recorded lectures.
Yeah but its a ton of work

Yes! As someone who grew up during this recession but did not really know the inner workings of what actually happened, this was a great course. I also think this class helps you understand the political narratives that popped up as a result of the crisis while also looking past them and evaluating events in a more objective way. I had taken intermediate level micro and macro before this course, and this course gave me the opportunity to see how those concepts play out in terms of policy. However, if you have a lot of other high-workload classes and/or are not good at time management, I might wait to take this course or take it when you have a lighter load.
